Use (patient-friendly): Used to reduce fever and relieve mild to moderate pain (headache, body pain).
One-line caution / safety note: Do not exceed recommended dose; check if taking other medicines containing paracetamol.
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: Safe if used as directed; avoid alcohol with high doses.
When to see doctor / red flags: If fever >3 days or severe pain

Use (patient-friendly): Relieves pain, inflammation (sprains, muscle pain), and fever.
One-line caution / safety note: Take with food to avoid stomach upset; avoid if stomach ulcers.
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: Can increase bleeding risk; avoid long-term without doctor.
When to see doctor / red flags: If severe stomach pain, blood in stool, or allergic reaction

Typical Adult Dose (simple): 300–600 mg for pain; low-dose 75–100 mg for heart protection
Use (patient-friendly): Used for pain/fever and low-dose used to prevent heart attacks.
One-line caution / safety note: Not for children with viral illness (risk of Reye's); can cause stomach bleeding.
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: Avoid before surgery unless advised by doctor.
When to see doctor / red flags: If signs of bleeding or severe stomach pain

Use (patient-friendly): Used for moderate pain and inflammation (arthritis, injuries).
One-line caution / safety note: Take with food; avoid if you have heart disease or stomach ulcers.
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: Long term use may increase heart risks.
When to see doctor / red flags: If chest pain, breathlessness, or severe abdominal pain

Use (patient-friendly): Used for pain and inflammation (muscle pain, arthritis).
One-line caution / safety note: Take with food; may upset stomach; avoid in heart disease unless advised.
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: Can cause dizziness; avoid heavy alcohol.
When to see doctor / red flags: If severe stomach bleeding or allergic reaction

Typical Adult Dose (simple): 500 mg every 8 hrs or 875 mg twice daily
Use (patient-friendly): Treats bacterial infections like ear infections, sore throat, some chest infections.
One-line caution / safety note: Do not share antibiotics; complete full prescribed course even if better.
When to see doctor / red flags: If rash, difficulty breathing, or severe diarrhea

Typical Adult Dose (simple): 500 mg day 1 then 250 mg daily for 2–4 days (depends)
Use (patient-friendly): Used for certain bacterial infections such as some throat and chest infections.
One-line caution / safety note: Do not share; complete course; some heart conditions need caution.
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: Can cause stomach upset; report severe diarrhea.
When to see doctor / red flags: If fast irregular heartbeat or severe allergic reaction

Use (patient-friendly): Used for certain serious bacterial infections (urinary, some gut infections).
One-line caution / safety note: Not for mild infections; can cause tendon problems; do not share.
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: Avoid in children and during pregnancy unless advised.
When to see doctor / red flags: If tendon pain, severe diarrhea, or neurological symptoms

Use (patient-friendly): Used for several bacterial infections; oral cephalosporin.
One-line caution / safety note: Do not share; complete full course.
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: If allergic to penicillin, check cross-reactivity.
When to see doctor / red flags: If rash, breathing difficulty, or worsening symptoms

Typical Adult Dose (simple): 100 mg twice daily for many uses
Use (patient-friendly): Used for infections like acne, some respiratory infections, malaria prophylaxis.
One-line caution / safety note: Avoid sunlight (can make you sunburn); not for young children or pregnancy.
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: May stain teeth in children; take with water to avoid irritation.
When to see doctor / red flags: If severe diarrhea or allergic reaction

Typical Adult Dose (simple): 400–500 mg two to three times daily
Use (patient-friendly): Used for certain bacterial and parasitic infections (abdominal, dental).
One-line caution / safety note: Avoid alcohol during and 48 hrs after treatment (can cause sick feeling).
When to see doctor / red flags: If numbness/tingling in hands or feet

Use (patient-friendly): Used for urinary and some respiratory infections.
One-line caution / safety note: Can cause allergic reactions; stay hydrated.
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: Avoid if allergy to sulfa drugs.
When to see doctor / red flags: If rash, mouth sores, or jaundice

Typical Adult Dose (simple): 100 mg twice daily for uncomplicated UTI
Use (patient-friendly): Used for bladder infections (urinary tract).
One-line caution / safety note: Take with food; not suitable for kidney problems.
When to see doctor / red flags: If breathing issues or fever with cough

Typical Adult Dose (simple): Single IM injection for some infections (admin by clinician)
Use (patient-friendly): Used for certain infections like rheumatic fever prevention / strep throat (clinician-admin).
One-line caution / safety note: Given by injection only; check allergy.
When to see doctor / red flags: If allergic reaction after injection

Use (patient-friendly): Used for various bacterial infections including chest infections.
One-line caution / safety note: Similar cautions to ciprofloxacin (tendon risk).
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: Avoid unnecessary use; do not share.
When to see doctor / red flags: If tendon pain or severe diarrhea

Use (patient-friendly): Used for respiratory infections and H. pylori combinations.
One-line caution / safety note: Can interact with other meds; follow doctor's advice.
When to see doctor / red flags: If irregular heartbeat or allergic reaction

Use (patient-friendly): Used for infections where bacteria make enzymes to resist simple penicillin.
One-line caution / safety note: Higher chance of stomach upset; complete course.
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: Watch for severe diarrhea or liver symptoms.
When to see doctor / red flags: If severe abdominal pain or jaundice

Typical Adult Dose (simple): Use as eye/ear drops as prescribed
Use (patient-friendly): Used for some eye/ear infections (topical).
One-line caution / safety note: Use only as prescribed; avoid prolonged application.
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: Systemic gentamicin is injectable and for hospital use.
When to see doctor / red flags: If eye redness or worsening pain

Use (patient-friendly): Used for skin and soft tissue infections caused by staph bacteria.
One-line caution / safety note: Complete course; check liver if prolonged use.
When to see doctor / red flags: If yellowing of skin or dark urine

Use (patient-friendly): Used for throat infections and mild infections.
One-line caution / safety note: Check allergy; complete course.
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: Follow dosing schedule; do not share.
When to see doctor / red flags: If rash or breathing difficulty

Typical Adult Dose (simple): 500 mg twice daily (start low, max 2000 mg/day)
Use (patient-friendly): First-line medicine for type 2 diabetes to lower blood sugar.
One-line caution / safety note: Take with food to reduce stomach upset; monitor blood sugar.
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: May cause GI upset initially; rare lactic acidosis in kidney disease.
When to see doctor / red flags: If dizziness, severe abdominal pain, or breathing trouble

Use (patient-friendly): Helps release insulin to lower blood sugar in type 2 diabetes.
One-line caution / safety note: Can cause low blood sugar (carry sugary snack).
When to see doctor / red flags: If fainting, sweating, or dizziness

Use (patient-friendly): Helps lower blood sugar; risk of hypoglycemia.
One-line caution / safety note: Take with breakfast; watch for low blood sugar.
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: Keep emergency sugar handy if symptoms appear.
When to see doctor / red flags: If repeated low blood sugar episodes

Use (patient-friendly): Helps control blood sugar by increasing incretin hormones.
One-line caution / safety note: Usually well tolerated; follow doctor’s dosing.
When to see doctor / red flags: If severe abdominal pain or allergic reaction

Use (patient-friendly): Helps remove excess sugar through urine; can reduce weight.
One-line caution / safety note: May cause increased urination and genital infections; stay hydrated.
When to see doctor / red flags: If fainting, severe infection, or ketoacidosis symptoms

Use (patient-friendly): Used to lower high blood pressure and relieve chest pain.
One-line caution / safety note: May cause swelling in ankles and flushing; avoid sudden stopping.
When to see doctor / red flags: If fainting or severe swelling

Use (patient-friendly): Used for high blood pressure and protecting kidneys in diabetes.
One-line caution / safety note: Avoid in pregnancy; monitor potassium.
When to see doctor / red flags: If pregnancy or severe lightheadedness

Use (patient-friendly): Lowers blood pressure; may protect heart/kidneys.
One-line caution / safety note: Can cause dry cough; avoid in pregnancy.
When to see doctor / red flags: If swelling of face/lips (angioedema)

Use (patient-friendly): Used for high blood pressure and heart rate control.
One-line caution / safety note: Do not stop abruptly; may cause fatigue or cold hands.
When to see doctor / red flags: If breathing problems or slow heartbeat

Use (patient-friendly): Used for blood pressure, heart rhythm, and chest pain.
One-line caution / safety note: Can cause tiredness; do not stop suddenly.
When to see doctor / red flags: If dizziness, fainting, or breathing trouble

Use (patient-friendly): Used for tremors, migraines, some heart conditions.
One-line caution / safety note: May worsen asthma; check with doctor.
When to see doctor / red flags: If breathing difficulty or very slow pulse

Use (patient-friendly): Used to lower cholesterol and reduce heart disease risk.
One-line caution / safety note: Take at any time of day; report unexplained muscle pain.
When to see doctor / red flags: If severe muscle pain or dark urine

Use (patient-friendly): Lowers cholesterol effectively.
One-line caution / safety note: Monitor liver tests if advised.
When to see doctor / red flags: If severe muscle pain or jaundice

Use (patient-friendly): Used for heart attack/stroke prevention (as advised by doctor).
One-line caution / safety note: Only take if prescribed; can increase bleeding risk.
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: Do not stop without consulting doctor.
When to see doctor / red flags: If bleeding or sudden severe symptoms

Use (patient-friendly): Reduces stomach acid for heartburn, ulcers, reflux.
One-line caution / safety note: Take before meals; not for immediate relief (takes days).
When to see doctor / red flags: If severe abdominal pain or black stools

Use (patient-friendly): Used for acid-related stomach issues.
One-line caution / safety note: Similar to omeprazole; follow duration instructions.
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: Avoid abrupt long-term use without review.
When to see doctor / red flags: If severe gastric bleeding signs

Use (patient-friendly): Used for heartburn and acid reflux relief.
One-line caution / safety note: Short term use is fine; follow instructions.
When to see doctor / red flags: If severe stomach bleeding signs

Use (patient-friendly): Used to prevent nausea and vomiting (after surgery/chemo).
One-line caution / safety note: May cause constipation or headache.
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: Use as prescribed by clinician for severe nausea.
When to see doctor / red flags: If severe constipation or allergic reaction

Typical Adult Dose (simple): 4 mg initially then 2 mg after each loose stool (max 8 mg OTC)
Use (patient-friendly): Stops diarrhea by slowing gut movement.
One-line caution / safety note: Not for bloody diarrhea or feverish infections; short-term use only.
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: Avoid if high fever or suspicion of infection.
When to see doctor / red flags: If diarrhea >48 hrs or blood in stool

Use (patient-friendly): Helps reduce fat absorption with fatty meals.
One-line caution / safety note: Can cause oily stools and gas; follow low-fat diet.
When to see doctor / red flags: If severe abdominal pain or persistent diarrhea

Use (patient-friendly): Used for allergy symptoms (sneezing, runny nose, itchy eyes).
One-line caution / safety note: May cause drowsiness in some people.
When to see doctor / red flags: If severe allergic reaction

Use (patient-friendly): Non-drowsy allergy relief for sneezing and itching.
One-line caution / safety note: Usually non-drowsy but check response.
When to see doctor / red flags: If severe breathing difficulty

Use (patient-friendly): Relief from allergies, similar to cetirizine.
One-line caution / safety note: May cause drowsiness in some.
When to see doctor / red flags: If severe symptoms

Use (patient-friendly): Relieves nasal congestion temporarily.
One-line caution / safety note: Can raise blood pressure and heart rate; avoid if high BP.
When to see doctor / red flags: If high blood pressure or chest pain

Use (patient-friendly): Milder nasal decongestant in many combos.
One-line caution / safety note: Less effective than pseudoephedrine for some; check labels.
When to see doctor / red flags: If chest symptoms or high BP

Use (patient-friendly): Relieves heartburn quickly by neutralizing acid and forming a barrier.
One-line caution / safety note: Short-term relief; follow instructions.
When to see doctor / red flags: If ongoing reflux or weight loss

Typical Adult Dose (simple): 1–2 puffs (100 mcg per puff) every 4–6 hrs as needed
Use (patient-friendly): Relieves wheeze and breathlessness in asthma/COPD quickly.
One-line caution / safety note: Use as rescue inhaler; not for long-term control alone.
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: Rinse mouth if using steroids too.
When to see doctor / red flags: If rescue inhaler doesn’t help or severe breathlessness

Use (patient-friendly): Used for daily control of asthma inflammation.
One-line caution / safety note: Not a rescue inhaler; use regularly for control.
When to see doctor / red flags: If worsening asthma or oral thrush

Use (patient-friendly): Helps control asthma and allergic rhinitis in some patients.
One-line caution / safety note: Not for acute asthma attacks; check mood side effects.
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: Report mood changes or severe reactions.
When to see doctor / red flags: If severe breathing difficulty

Typical Adult Dose (simple): Apply thinly to affected area 1–2 times daily
Use (patient-friendly): Used for mild eczema, rashes, and insect bites.
One-line caution / safety note: Short-term use only on small areas; avoid face long-term.
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: May thin skin with prolonged use.
When to see doctor / red flags: If skin infection signs or spreading rash

Use (patient-friendly): Treats ringworm, athlete's foot, and yeast infections on skin.
One-line caution / safety note: Keep area clean and dry while treating.
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: Stop and see doctor if no improvement.
When to see doctor / red flags: If severe spreading or face involvement

Typical Adult Dose (simple): 150 mg single dose for vaginal yeast (varies)
Use (patient-friendly): Used for fungal infections like thrush and some systemic uses.
One-line caution / safety note: Follow instructions; report liver symptoms.
When to see doctor / red flags: If jaundice or severe stomach pain

Typical Adult Dose (simple): Use as oral suspension as prescribed
Use (patient-friendly): Used for oral thrush in babies/elderly (apply or swish and swallow).
One-line caution / safety note: Follow pediatric dosing; keep hygiene.
When to see doctor / red flags: If difficulty swallowing or severe infection

Use (patient-friendly): Used for severe itching or anxiety in some cases.
One-line caution / safety note: Causes drowsiness; avoid driving.
When to see doctor / red flags: If extreme drowsiness or breathing trouble

Typical Adult Dose (simple): Topical applied 5 times daily; oral dosing varies
Use (patient-friendly): Used for cold sores and herpes infections.
One-line caution / safety note: Start early in infection for best effect.
When to see doctor / red flags: If severe or spreading infection

Use (patient-friendly): Used for influenza treatment if started early.
One-line caution / safety note: Not a substitute for vaccine; start early.
When to see doctor / red flags: If severe breathing difficulty

Use (patient-friendly): Prevents blood clots; used after some surgeries or for AF.
One-line caution / safety note: Requires regular blood test monitoring (INR); many interactions.
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: Do not start/stop without doctor and check interactions.
When to see doctor / red flags: If unusual bleeding or bruising

Use (patient-friendly): Prevents platelets from sticking; used after stents or heart events.
One-line caution / safety note: Only take if prescribed; increases bleeding risk.
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: Avoid sudden stopping without medical advice.
When to see doctor / red flags: If bleeding or unexpected bruising

Use (patient-friendly): Replaces thyroid hormone for underactive thyroid.
One-line caution / safety note: Take on empty stomach; keep consistent timing.
When to see doctor / red flags: If palpitations or worsening symptoms

Use (patient-friendly): Used for severe acne under dermatologist supervision.
One-line caution / safety note: Highly teratogenic—strict pregnancy prevention needed.
When to see doctor / red flags: If pregnancy or severe mood change

Use (patient-friendly): Used for acne and skin renewal.
One-line caution / safety note: Can cause dryness and sun sensitivity; use sunscreen.
When to see doctor / red flags: If severe irritation

Typical Adult Dose (simple): As per label (e.g., Calcium 500 mg + D3 400 IU)
Use (patient-friendly): Used to support bone health.
One-line caution / safety note: Do not exceed recommended dose; check interactions with other meds.
When to see doctor / red flags: If severe constipation or kidney stones history

Use (patient-friendly): Used for iron-deficiency anemia to increase blood iron.
One-line caution / safety note: May cause constipation and dark stools; take with vitamin C to help absorption.
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: Avoid taking with tea/coffee and calcium at same time.
When to see doctor / red flags: If signs of severe anemia or allergic reaction

Use (patient-friendly): General nutritional supplement for deficiency prevention.
One-line caution / safety note: Not a replacement for a healthy diet; avoid mega-doses.
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: Check if on specialized meds (warfarin interactions).
When to see doctor / red flags: If allergic reaction

Use (patient-friendly): Used for hay fever and nasal allergy control.
One-line caution / safety note: Regular daily use gives best effect; not immediate.
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: Shake before use; may take days to work.
When to see doctor / red flags: If nosebleeds or severe irritation

Use (patient-friendly): Moisturizes nose and helps clear mucus.
One-line caution / safety note: Safe for all ages; useful adjunct.
When to see doctor / red flags: If severe sinus pain or high fever

Use (patient-friendly): Allergy relief for children
One-line caution / safety note: Check pediatric dosing
When to see doctor / red flags: If breathing difficulty

Use (patient-friendly): Helps with allergies and sleep short-term
One-line caution / safety note: Causes drowsiness; avoid driving
When to see doctor / red flags: If severe allergic reaction

Use (patient-friendly): Helps lower blood pressure by removing extra fluid
One-line caution / safety note: May increase urination; monitor electrolytes
When to see doctor / red flags: If dizziness or dehydration

Use (patient-friendly): Used for fluid retention and some BP cases
One-line caution / safety note: Can increase potassium; monitor labs
When to see doctor / red flags: If muscle weakness or palpitations

Use (patient-friendly): Used for inflammation and allergic reactions short-term
One-line caution / safety note: Do not stop abruptly after long use; short courses usually safe
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: If high blood sugar or infection
When to see doctor / red flags: If high blood sugar or infection

Use (patient-friendly): Allergic rhinitis control
One-line caution / safety note: Regular use gives best control
When to see doctor / red flags: If nosebleeds

Use (patient-friendly): Helps erectile dysfunction
One-line caution / safety note: Do not take with nitrates (heart meds)
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: If chest pain or severe dizziness
When to see doctor / red flags: If chest pain or severe dizziness

Use (patient-friendly): Helps erectile dysfunction
One-line caution / safety note: Avoid nitrates; can lower blood pressure
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: If sudden vision loss or chest pain
When to see doctor / red flags: If sudden vision loss or chest pain

Typical Adult Dose (simple): Use one dose under tongue as directed
Use (patient-friendly): Relieves chest pain from heart angina
One-line caution / safety note: Use sitting; can cause headache and low BP
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: If chest pain persists after 3 doses
When to see doctor / red flags: If chest pain persists after 3 doses

Use (patient-friendly): Suppresses dry cough temporarily
One-line caution / safety note: Not for productive cough with mucus
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: If high fever or green phlegm
When to see doctor / red flags: If high fever or green phlegm

Use (patient-friendly): Helps thin mucus in chest
One-line caution / safety note: Drink fluids to help loosen mucus
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: If cough >2 weeks or bloody sputum
When to see doctor / red flags: If cough >2 weeks or bloody sputum

Use (patient-friendly): Numbs the throat to reduce cough
One-line caution / safety note: Do not chew (can numb mouth), keep away from children
When to see doctor / red flags: If breathing difficulty

Use (patient-friendly): Prevent/treat minor wound infections
One-line caution / safety note: Allergy to neomycin possible
When to see doctor / red flags: If spread of infection

Use (patient-friendly): Clean minor wounds
One-line caution / safety note: Not for deep wounds; use gentle cleaning
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: If deep wound or heavy bleeding
When to see doctor / red flags: If deep wound or heavy bleeding

Use (patient-friendly): Used for impetigo and infected small wounds
One-line caution / safety note: Use short-term; do not ingest
When to see doctor / red flags: If larger area infected

Typical Adult Dose (simple): Use as per label weekly or twice weekly
Use (patient-friendly): Treats dandruff and fungal scalp infections
One-line caution / safety note: Avoid contact with eyes
When to see doctor / red flags: If rash worsens

Typical Adult Dose (simple): Apply as per label twice daily
Use (patient-friendly): Helps in hair regrowth for some patterns
One-line caution / safety note: May cause scalp irritation; results take months
When to see doctor / red flags: If scalp irritation severe

Use (patient-friendly): Helps urine flow in men with enlarged prostate
One-line caution / safety note: May cause dizziness on standing

Use (patient-friendly): Helps reduce prostate size or hair loss prevention
One-line caution / safety note: Not for use in women; avoid handling crushed pills in pregnancy
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: If breast changes or sexual side effects
When to see doctor / red flags: If breast changes or sexual side effects

Use (patient-friendly): Lowers cholesterol often with statin
One-line caution / safety note: Follow lipid tests
When to see doctor / red flags: If muscle pain

Use (patient-friendly): Check liver and muscle symptoms
One-line caution / safety note: If severe muscle pain

Use (patient-friendly): Helps with vomiting/nausea and gastric emptying
One-line caution / safety note: Short-term use; long-term can cause movement disorders
When to see doctor / red flags: If involuntary movements

Use (patient-friendly): Helps nausea and vomiting (some countries restrict)
One-line caution / safety note: Check for cardiac risk; follow dosing
When to see doctor / red flags: If irregular heartbeat

Use (patient-friendly): Prevents blood clots; alternative to warfarin
One-line caution / safety note: Do not stop without advice; bleeding risk
When to see doctor / red flags: If bleeding or severe bruising

Use (patient-friendly): Prevent/treat blood clots
One-line caution / safety note: Similar bleeding cautions

Use (patient-friendly): Control asthma/COPD symptoms long-term
One-line caution / safety note: Rinse mouth after steroid inhaler

Use (patient-friendly): Used for COPD control
One-line caution / safety note: Follow inhaler technique; not rescue

Use (patient-friendly): Reduces muscle spasm in certain conditions
One-line caution / safety note: Can cause drowsiness; avoid alcohol

Use (patient-friendly): Used for nerve pain and seizures
One-line caution / safety note: Can cause dizziness and sleepiness
Extra note (interactions/allergy/monitor: If mood change or severe dizziness

Use (patient-friendly): Used for nerve pain and fibromyalgia
One-line caution / safety note: Drowsiness and weight gain possible

Use (patient-friendly): Relieves severe migraine in many cases

Use (patient-friendly): Reduces acne and rosacea redness
One-line caution / safety note: May cause mild irritation

Use (patient-friendly): Used for malaria and some autoimmune conditions

Use (patient-friendly): Used for certain malaria species and for radical cure
One-line caution / safety note: G6PD testing needed before use

Use (patient-friendly): Used in some malaria treatments (local guidance)

Use (patient-friendly): Used for period pain and other pains
One-line caution / safety note: Can cause stomach upset and bleeding risk
